The limit is only making an observation: although it may be impossible to for the algorithm to draw a perfect circle, you can make get as close to a circle as you like by performing a sufficient number of iterations.

For example, consider the function: sin(x)/x
The value at x=0 is undefined, and at all other values, is strictly below 1 (and somewhere above -0.22).
When we say the limit f(x) as x->0 = 1, that doesn't mean we can actually find sin(0)/0. It means we can make the value as close to 0 as we like, by selecting a value of x as close to 0 as we need.

For the circle limit deriving pi as 4, the issue is that on the parametric, if you chop up the parametric space into equal parts and then correlate those with their matching wedges of the circle, the wedges are not all the same size. The wedges near t = 1/8, 3/8, 5/8, and 7/8 are smallest while near t = 0, 1/4, 1/2, and 3/4 are the largest.

The sphere proof is incorrect because of the assumption that curved space behaves similarly to flat space. The triangles on the sphere have completely different properties than they do on a plane. What this proof is effectively doing, is creating a transformation that projects the triangles from the spherical space, to a flat space. As the triangles get smaller, this transformation is still applied. The formula that is being obtained by this proof IS the surface area of the sphere, except it is the area AFTER it has been projected onto a flat plane. This projected area is completely different from the actual area of a sphere. It is equivalent to taking the area of something on a flat world map and saying that is the actual land area of whatever it's equivalent is on the globe.

Base case: for a group of one single horse this is trivially true.

Induction Assumption: any group of 1<n horses or less have the same color.

By definition of the number line, 3-1=2 and 2-1=1.
By definition of the term "A is greater than B" (denoted by the expression A>B), A is neither equal to nor lesser than B (A≤B is false if A>B).
By definition of the greater than (>) and less than (<) operators, A>B means B<A.
By transitive property of order, A>B>C means A>C. This holds true even if A is greater than or equal to B (A≥B), OR if B is greater than or equal to C (B≥C), but not if both alternatives are true. So A>C if A>B≥C or A≥B>C, but not A≥B≥C. In that case, A≥C.
If 2>3, then 2-1>3-1 (meaning 1>2, or 2<1).
If you subtract a lower integer from a higher integer, the result must be an integer greater than or equal to 1, so 3-1≥1. Therefore, 2 is greater than or equal to 1 so long as 3-1=2.

Curvature is amazingly described by a tensor field, which is the technical way to say that it's intrinsic and its value at a point depends only on the vectors tangent to the surface at that point. In other words, it's not generally true that curved spaces look locally flat (in the way that mathematicians use that term).

What you're describing is better understood through parallel transport, which intuitively is like moving a vector along a curve without changing its orientation. The relevant result here is that if you parallel translate a vector along some triangle on a curved surface, you don't typically end up with the same vector you started with. They are only the same to a first order approximation (with respect to the side lengths of the triangle). The second order term is exactly the curvature at your starting point. So if you shrink the side lengths of the triangle, the original vector and its parallel transport become closer to being the same. This is morally akin to saying "the surface is locally linear." But linear is a dangerous word here, because it refers to vector space structures and the use of calculus. In the sense of curvature, the space retains its non-linearity.

If one wants to know more rigorously what happens in the second "proof", it essentially means that the uniform limit of curves, that is, the limit in the C^0 topology, does not necessarily preserve lengths of curves. This is indicative of the fact that "length" is not an innate property of curves that are only continuous, as many continuous curves do not necessarily have a well defined length (fractal curves for example). You would need what is defined as a rectifiable curve in order to talk about it's length. If one considers, on the other hand, curves that are piecewise smooth and they have a well defined limit in the C^1 topology, that is, their derivatives (ergo their velocities) also have a limit, then length is in fact preserved. The jagged curves approximating the circle do not have their velocities converging uniformly to the "velocity" (or the tangent velocities) of a circular path, hence it does not converge in the C^1 topology. Even more thoroughly, one could imagine the most general space on which a C^1 topology makes sense, and one would have to start dealing with Sobolev spaces from functional analysis. I find this remarkable in that it shows that even though our intuition fails, mathematics finds a way to rescue a significant and meaninguful portion of it on a maybe more subtle or advanced context, but nethertheless a correct and rigorous one.

Regarding the questions at 16:55, if the function is continuous and you are integrating over a closed interval, then I think I have proved that the error does go to zero. My proof uses the fact that a closed interval is "compact", something which would be just as difficult to prove if you didn't already know it!

Suppose we pick an e > 0, and we want the error from the rectangles to be less than e. We divide e by the horizontal length, and then by 2, to get e'. As long as the height of a rectangle is always within 2e' of the actual value of the function we are good.

For each x in the interval, if the function is continuous there is a value dx such that for all k in x-dx < k < x+dx we have f(x)-e' < f(k) < f(x)+e' - simply put, there is a small range of x where f(x) does not wobble up or down too much. We define the neighbourhood of x, Nx, to be the interval (x- dx/3, x + dx/3) ie the middle third of this safe area.

As each value of x is the middle of the corresponding Nx, all the Nx s together cover the whole range. And they are all open sets. So, because the line interval is compact, we can select a finite number of them which between them cover the whole length. This is important because, while the dx s for all the Nx s may go smaller and smaller, for only a finite number of Nx s there must be a positive lower limit dmin which is >0. Let d be dmin/3. And let us insist that the rectangles can be no wider than d.

Now, take any value k in the range. At k, the function has the value f(k) and the rectangle has the height f(m) for some m within d of k. k must be in a selected neighbourhood Nx for some x. k is within d of x, and so m must be within 2d of x. This is still within the "safe area", so f(k) and f(m) are both within e' of f(x) and so are within 2e' of each other.

I think I can answer the first two questions at once by pointing out that this looks suspiciously like Riemann integration, which is possible if and only if the function in question is continuous almost everywhere on a closed bounded interval (that is, continuous except on a set of measure zero). If I had to guess, I would say that the error goes to 0 if and only if the function is continuous almost everywhere.

If I am correct on this point, then it is quite simple to construct an example where the error does not go to 0: the Dirichlet function, which assigns 1 to rational numbers and 0 to irrational numbers. Let's examine this function on [0,1]. It is easy to show that this function is continuous nowhere, so it is not Riemann integrable on [0,1], or any interval for that matter. Thus, the "error" would not approach 0.

However, this prompts the question of how we would even define "error" anyway, which is closely related to how we would define area. One possible definition for area under a curve is the Riemann integral of that curve, provided that the integral exists. Thus, error would be defined as the magnitude of the difference between the approximated area, with whatever approximation we are using, and the Riemann integral. If we take this to be our definition, then in our previous example, we can't even say that the error doesn't approach 0 because the error is not even defined.

I also know that another way to define area would be Lebesgue measure on R^2, but unfortunately, we did not get to cover this in my analysis courses (we only discussed Lebesgue measure on R). Thus, I do not know whether the region between the Dirichlet function and the x-axis from x=0 to x=1 is Lebesgue measurable, or if this would coincide with the Lebesgue integral of this function from 0 to 1. If you want a proof that the angle bisector never crosses the perpendicular bisector of the opposite side inside the triangle:
1. imagine a non-isoceles triangle like the one in the proof. Picture the top point leaning towards the right.
2. Bisect the bottom side of the triangle and draw a line from the top angle to the bisection point.
3. Let's call the top two angles A1 (on the left) and A2 (on the right) and the lengths of the corresponding opposing sides (that together make up the bisected line) 'a' (we can use the same for both because they're equal). Let's call the line from the top to the bisection point L, and the remaining angles of the original triangle B (on the left) and C (on the right).
4. The law of sines says that the proportion of the sine of an angle to the length of the opposite side is equal for all angles of the triangle. So for the left triangle section, Sin(A1) / a = Sin(B) / L and for the right triangle section, Sin(A2) / a = Sin(C) / L.

Divide one equality by the other and you get
Sin(A1)/Sin(A2) = Sin(B)/Sin(C)
Remember that our top point is biased towards the right side of the perpendicular bisector, which if you look at the triangle, you can tell that angle B is greater than angle C. This leaves two possibilities:
1. Both B and C are acute which means, since Sin between 0 and 90 degrees only goes up as the angle increases (look at a graph of a Sine wave if you don't believe me, the top of the first "hump" going right is 90 degrees), and angle C is greater than angle B, so Sin(C) > Sin(B)
2. B is potentially obtuse, which means you have to do a bit more work
The sine of an obtuse angle equals the sine of its supplement (180 degrees - that angle) and since there are only 180 degrees in the triangle in the first place, A + B + C = 180, so 180 - C has to be B + A, which means the supplement of C is more than B and therefore Sin(C) > Sin(B)

Now that we've proven Sin(C) > Sin(B), that means Sin(B) / Sin(C) is less than 1 (larger denominator than numerator). Which since Sin(A1)/Sin(A2) = Sin(B)/Sin(C), Sin(A1)/Sin(A2) is also less than 1. Again, the larger denominator than numerator required to get a quotient less than 1, means Sin(A2) > Sin(A1).

I will now prove A1 is acute. The angle between L and the left side of "a" is obtuse, because the top point is to the right of the perpendicular bisector; since A1 is in the same triangle as that angle, A1 must be acute (a triangle can't have two obtuse angles). This leaves two possibilities:

1. A2 is obtuse, which since A1 isn't, means A2 > A1, which means the angle bisector line is to the right of the line we've currently drawn
2. A2 is acute, which for the reason stated earlier, Sin(A2) > Sin(A1) when both are acute means that A2 > A1, which means the angle bisector line is to the right of the line we've currently drawn.

The claim of the circle proof is the the tangential intersections of the square and then the figures derived from the square eventually add up to the length of the circumference. For this to be true, the set of these intersecting points has to be equal to the set of points in the interval [0,C], where C is the circumference of the circle. It is known that the number of points along a given non-infinitesimal interval is equal to aleph_1, so the number of points that the square sequence converges to has to be equal to aleph_1.

If we start with the square, it intersects the circle at 4 points. After we perform the "division" operation, and the corners of the square are folded in, we have 8 intersections. If we do it again, we have 16 intersections, and so on. This sequence can be arranged as such: 4, 8, 16, 32, 64..., which can be arranged in 1-1 correspondence with the natural numbers: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5... What this mean is that the number of intersections converge to countable infinity, or aleph_0, and can not be a bijection of the set aleph_1. Therefore the two shapes never converge to each other and the circumference of the circle is not 4.

This video manages to show that "drawings" used in euclidean geometry are just intuitive diagrams and they cannot be considered by themselves rigorous proofs. The first reason is explained in the video:

- Drawings are affected by finite precision problems.

The second (more pedantic) reason is: how in the world do you formalize drawings in an axiomatic way?

In principle, the Elements of Euclid (and really any rigorous mathematics book) could have be written without any drawings and they would have been more mathematically correct (because Euclid would have noticed some of his "mistakes" like assuming the existence of some intersection points).

I'm not saying that drawings should be abolished. I'm just saying that believing that your drawing is a mathematical object in the strict sense is a lie and it's the first step to become unrigorous.

Drawings are just useful diagrams. And they are useful because geometry has been axiomatized in order for them to be useful, since they are the "object of study" of geometry. But this doesn't make them a mathematical object.

In mathematics this is a pretty common way to formalise unrigorous but intuitive objects. You reverse-engineer your intuition in order to create feasible axioms and then you add some axioms if you need them and they match your intuition. This process can take also centuries of refinement among mathematicians to decide which axioms should be conventionally used. Some example:

-Group axioms

-Topological spaces axioms

-Vector spaces axioms

-Probability axioms

-ZFC axioms

...

The definitions of lengths of curves and of areas of surfaces represent accumulated wisdom and foreknowledge of these appealing yet troublesome arguments. By which I mean, I think (?) you can get a consistent logical system by, for instance, entertaining multiple arguments to demonstrate circles don't have a well-defined circumference at all. We've rejected that approach, for multiple reasons. We've instead agreed on a definition of the length of a non-straight curve -- which comes packaged with a way to resolve whether the length of a curve is well-defined. That definition is the ultimate authority used to refute those two proofs

The third proof's error is that the perpendicular bisector of the base of an isosceles triangle cannot intersect the angle bisector of the opposite angle in only a single point. It must, by definition, intersect as a line--because the perpendicular bisector of the base is the same line. By presuming that there can be a singular point P where the angle bisector of BAC intersects the perpendicular bisector of BC, you have inserted a contradiction, and thus everything which follows from that contradiction is erroneous.

Let's prove pi = 0.

For this proof I'll denote by Int(a,b) f(x) dx the integral of f(x) from a to b, as I can't or don't know how to put the integral symbol in youtube.

Naturaly, we have

pi = Int(0,pi) 1 dx.

The idea is to make a variable change using u=sin(x). Then du/dx=cos(x) such that dx=1/cos(x) du and, therefore,

pi = Int(0,pi) 1 dx = Int(u(0),u(pi)) 1/cos(x) du = Int(0,0) 1/cos(x) du.

I'm quite proud of myself for actually figuring out that isoceles triangle proof. And I had a few things to add about it:

- If the triangle truly was isoceles, then the angle bisector of A and the perpendicular bisector of B and C are actually THE SAME LINE, meaning their intersection point (P) is undefined. So if anything, the existence of point P is enough to prove that the triangle is not isoceles (or rather, that those two particular sides are not equal to each other).

- AF really does equal AE, and FB really does equal EC. However, since either E or F must be outside the triangle, that means that one of the sides must equal AE+EC and the other must equal AE-EC. So essentially what we've done with this "proof" is, we found a new way to construct a line equalling the average of AB and AC, plus another line equalling half the difference between AB and AC. (Of course, if that was your original goal, there are far easier ways to do this - but I think it's interesting nonetheless.)

The flaw in the triangle one: AF + FB = AB ONLY holds true if F lies between A & B. This is never explicitly checked for, although If P lies inside ABC it should always be so. What's interesting about the 3rd "proof", is -- geometry being what it is, it's quite simple, it doesn't mind signs, or even complex numbers -- *as long as you are consistent with them*. Which is of course the problem as shown: a lack of consistency. Handled properly, geometry doesn't much care if you have negative or complex lengths. You can get some interesting (if maybe not particularly useful) insights when considering "out of range" values, when applied to a lot of theorems/problems. And, I would say, building an intuition about this expanded problem space (including negative lengths, areas, etc.) helps hone ones' intuition about what equations can arise from that geometry.

Even entering "wrong" numbers, say to the Pythagorean Theorem, gives a certain amount of rightness: an imaginary length can be thought of as, say, an effective width/thickness of a line, i.e. a dimension perpendicular to its apparent direction; or as a "height" in a new dimension perpendicular entirely to the plane. Consider a dumb-3-4-5 right triangle: let c = 4, b = 5, and a = sqrt(c^2 - b^2) = ±3i. A hypotenuse of 4, with a base length of 5, does not, a right triangle, make!

There is no angle we can draw the hypotenuse at, which connects with the altitude (length a), while still drawing it perpendicular to the base (length b). At best, we could draw the hypotenuse parallel to the base, coming up short by 1 unit from the base length. But we could also claim that the altitude is 3i long, effectively extended widthwise to reach the "hypotenuse". (That the minimum length difference is 1, while the complex magnitude is 3, is less easy to imagine, I'll admit!)

The fun thing about this is that Euclid must have known about this problem, as did the geometers whose theorems he wrote about. Euclid uses several visual proofs in his Elements which are fallacious by modern standards, but whenever his axioms were sufficient for a more rigorous proof, he gave the better one. It's as if he recognized the deficiencies in some of his proofs but just knew of no better proof. Some of these are sort of trivial, like his very first proposition for the construction of an equilateral triangle (which assumes without proof that two circles, each passing through the other's center, must intersect), but others are absolutely essential to the axiomatic system he is setting up. His fallacious proof of SAS congruence might be the best example, because it is pretty much impossible to interpret in the modern day. He simply does not invoke his own axioms at all, instead using some sort of argument by translation, presumably based on what he felt was obvious.

And I like the example of arclengths too, because ancient geometers suspected that it was simply impossible to define the length of an arc that wasn't piecewise straight. Archimedes disagreed and introduced some clever elementary axioms that allowed him to prove things about the circumference of a circle and surface areas of a cylinder, cone, and sphere. He was mostly interested in convex curves, because proving anything about general curves was not feasible using the tools of the time. This example of nonconvex polygons approaching a circle pointwise might not have been known to Archimedes, but a similar example of them approaching a right triangle probably was. These apparently paradoxical cases (where the limit of the arclengths of a sequence of curves does not equal the arclength of their pointwise limit, even though both are defined) might have dissuaded him from tackling nonconvex curves altogether. This is an example where modern calculus is genuinely superior to ancient reasoning, and where we couldn't make meaningful progress without the set of real numbers.

I remember, when I was a "child" (14 years old), I asked my math teacher why the length of the diagonal of a square isn't twice the length of one side, with the same reasoning as you did with the circle, bending the corner over and over until, at the limit, there's just a straight line which is the diagonal. This really haunted me for days, I couldn't figure out why that was wrong (I obviously knew about Pythagoras' theorem). He tried to explain to me the way you did, how it is not always possible to assume that f(lim x_n) = lim f(x_n), but he couldn't really give me a formal answer to *why* this doesn't work. By that I mean, yes, we can't say the length of the limit is the limit of the lengths because our example shows it's not true, but it doesn't explain why it's not true. It's only years later, when I learnt about function sequences and their convergences, and also about what's a curve and what's the length of a curve (at least of class C^1 piecewise), that I could fully understand what's going wrong.
For the ones who don't know, the length of a curve is given by the integral of it's derivative (in modulus, or norm if you consider it over a normed vector space). If you have a sequence of functions (f_n) that converges uniformly to a limit f, even if they all are of class C^1, the sequence of their derivatives doesn't not necessarily converges to f'. This means the sequence of their lengths doesn't necessarily converges to the length of f. In other words, the length function isn't continuous. Knowing that, it is also quite easy to create a sequence of curves that converges to a circle (or a segment), but with their sequence of length diverging towards infinity (think of the sequence of function (1/n sin(n^2 x)) )

That would be fine for the false proof you showed as long as the perpendicular bisector points back “inward”, but it’s easy to see that the PB will tilt the exact opposite way, so the AB and PB always intersect outside of the triangle in scalene triangles.
